---
title: 'Climate, Conflict and Society: Changing Responses to Weather Extremes in Nineteenth
  Century Zululand'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-MEH7SBTG" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Klein, J., Nash, D., Pribyl, K., Endfield, G., &#38; Matthew, H. (2018). <div id="csl-bib-meta-MEH7SBTG" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-MEH7SBTG" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Klein et al. examined how changing weather patterns influenced society and conflict in nineteenth-century Zululand. They reviewed debates on how climate change affected the rise of the Zulu Kingdom and analyzed new evidence from archival materials and oral histories. Their findings suggest that drier conditions led to significant societal changes, including shifts in rain-control practices, migration, and increased conflict. These responses varied depending on leadership and power structures. This study highlights the complex relationship between climate and society, showing that environmental changes can deeply impact social stability and cultural practices. Understanding these historical interactions can help us better address current climate challenges and their effects on communities.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-MEH7SBTG" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Climate Change, Conflict, Society, Nineteenth Century, Zululand, Precipitation Patterns
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-MEH7SBTG" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    Changing climates affect human societies differently depending on societal structures, cultural perceptions and their relative vulnerability and resilience. In this study, we explore the complex relationship between climate, conflict and society in nineteenth century Zululand. The paper first reviews current debates surrounding the links between climatic change, societal transformation and the rise of the Zulu Kingdom from the late-eighteenth to early-nineteenth centuries. It then considers new empirical evidence relating to conflict and socio-economic changes at a local scale in Zululand from theearly-mid-nineteenth century onwards, using a combination of unpublished archival 
materials written by missionaries and other observers, together with oral histories and traditions. Our analysis highlights how changing precipitation patterns, especially towards drier conditions, may have contributed to changes 
in societal responses, including dominant narratives about rain-control, the migration and dissolution of society, and conflicts and unrest. We suggest that temporal differences in these responses were contingent upon the role of leaders, 
power structures, and the willingness and ability of leaders to yield this power. The case of nineteenth century Zululand exemplifies the complexity of environment–society interactions, and strengthens the call for a thorough 
scrutiny of the narratives of social unrest in specific socio-cultural contexts.
  </article>
